text:
Hi guys, I'm Laura Vitale and on this episode
of Laura in the Kitchen I want to show you
how to make a stuffed focaccia.

Now this is going to take no time at all because
we are going to have - we are going to make

it with some prepared pizza dough that I always
happen to have on hand in my freezer. It's

one of my standby ingredients, but you can
buy a homemade pizza dough at your local grocery

store. They'll actually make pizza dough in
there.

Or you can go to your local pizza shop and
buy a couple balls of pizza dough if you don't

want to make your own.
I do suggest you make your own and my recipe
is - I think is the easiest in the world.

So, aside from pizza dough, what you stuff
this with is completely up to you.

Now, Joe and I are going to be going out of
town in just a few days, so I, like any other

woman on the - you know I'm on a quest to
use up everything in my fridge!

So I just raided my fridge and I used up - I
just grabbed things I already had opened that
I wanted to use up.

So, going to have some pizza dough - you need
two one pound balls of pizza dough. Then I

have some marinated artichoke hearts, some
kalamata olives that I've chopped up, some

marinated mushrooms, some roasted bell peppers.
I've got some baby spinach that's been washed
and dried.
And then I've got some shredded mozzarella.

You need some fresh rosemary and some really
good quality extra virgin olive oil, some
sea salt and some course black pepper.
That's it!

Now, I love - and you guys know this about
me if you've been following me for a long

time - I love anything sort of vinegary and
marinated and pickled, so I tend to always

have a few jars of marinated vegetables on
hand because they're great to put together
for last minute antipasti or what not.

I'm just taking one of my balls of pizza dough
that kind of stuck together a little bit,
that's okay.
Shake off the excess flour.
Actually just..

And now what I've got here is my Sicilian
pan - my Sicilian pizza pan I should call
this, because that's what it is.

And I have oiled this well with some olive
oil.

Now, the thing that makes - in my opinion
- focaccia so outstanding is the fact that

it's just got that beautiful olive oil flavor
pretty much running through it. And it's really

fluffy and dimply and has the rosemary and
the sea salt. It's phenomenal.

And we are going to get all that gorgeous
flavor but by using some pre-made pizza dough.

But if you do want to make a traditional focaccia
bread, LauraintheKitchen.com has got you covered
with a recipe, of course!

All I'm doing, as you can see, now this isn't
going to stretch out completely, corner to

That's pretty much good enough for me. I mean
I'm not being picky about this at all.

It is looking on the pretty thin side over

a bit so it'll be just fine.

And now all I'm going to do is just top it
with my toppings.

Now, I put my - anything marinated I put them
in a bowl before I start to get ready that

way all the marinating juice kind of falls
down.

Because you don't want that, otherwise it'll
make things soggy.

So just spread this out and then scatter the
spinach on top as well.
That looks good!

You can see I left a border around - about

And then I've got some shredded mozzarella,

Because it's great for anything and everything.

There are certain things that you'll always

dough is right at the top of the things that

so much that you can do with it from garlic

Now, here's what I'm going to do so that you

Set that aside for just a minute.

I'm taking this other pizza dough, and I'm

a little bit, just to stretch it out.

Because I obviously, can't put it on top of

Now you might be thinking to yourself 'well
why don't you just call this a stuffed pizza
because you're using pizza dough?'.

Well, we're going to let this rise a little
bit, we're going to let it relax, it's going

to get all soft and dimply with that flavorful
olive oil and rosemary, which is very reminiscent

of a focaccia, that's why I call it a stuffed
focaccia instead of a stuffed pizza.

So all I'm doing is just kind of stretching

semi-rectangle.

And then once you've got it stretched out
enough, I just - you stretch it out.

And then my pizza dough, I have to say, and
I think a lot of you out there can vouch for

this, because I know a lot of you have made

so it's not going to freak out, it's not going
to get mad at you and snap back.

If it's risen really nicely, it works out
really, really well. It's just real easy.

And then once I pinch it, I just, I kind of

See I'm just taking my two fingers and rolling

This is just some really good quality extra

it's beautiful, huh?

And when I say a good quality, what I mean
is, because it's all so different for everybody

and our preferences, whatever you can splurge
on that's ideally the most expensive in your

local grocery store is what I would consider
is a good quality extra virgin olive oil.

This is not an olive oil that I would saute
things with, because the flavor is going to

evaporate anyway, pretty much, but this is
- if you want the olive oil to be the star

of a show, you use a really good one. So,

a couple of slits, real small ones on the
top just to let any air escape.

And now, I'm going to just take my fingers
and I'm going to just make little dimples

A little coarse ground pepper. I like coarse

Some sea salt.
Nice and coarse.
Ahh, look at that!
Just love it!

And then some fresh rosemary, I'm not even
going to chop it, I"m just going to take the
leaves and just scatter them about.
This to me is the smell and flavor of focaccia.

You could use dried rosemary if you want to,

just really prefer fresh because, you know,

Now, I'm going to cover this with a lint-free

I'm going to cover this with two pieces of

I will say this, if you are planning on using
the same sort of toppings - or filling - I

used, sort of pickled things, things that
get really kind of wet, you have to eat this
right away for the best results.

If you're using something like salami and
prosciutto, and provolone, it stays really

well in the fridge, but if you're using things
that are wet, it will get soggy so you're

going to have to eat this - it's best to eat
it the night you make it, or the day you make
it.

We're going to go and enjoy this, LauraintheKitchen.com
